case_vignette: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his wife because of a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm. He also reports that he cannot move his right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on his side. He is otherwise healthy. He works as a waiter and says that he feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. He adds that he “can barely keep his eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. He has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pin prick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing severe pain in my right arm for the past 3 days, and I can't move it at all.
Is this pain accompanied by numbness or tingling sensations?
Yes, I can't feel light touch over my entire right arm and forearm.
Have you recently suffered any injuries or experienced any trauma to your right arm?
No, it just started hurting after I woke up one morning.

Have you noticed any weakness or muscle wasting in your right arm?

**Final Diagnosis:** Cervical Radiculopathy or Brachial Plexus Injury. Further tests are needed for confirmation.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents at the clinic with severe pain in the right arm for the past 3 days, with complete inability to move it. The patient also reports an absence of light touch sensation throughout the entire right arm and forearm. The pain started after waking up one morning.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Conversion disorder.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is a cervical radiculopathy, specifically C6-C7 nerve root compression. This condition can present with symptoms of arm pain, weakness, and sensory loss, often following a period of sleep or physical exertion. The rapid withdrawal to a pinprick test is consistent with hyperalgesia, a common finding in radiculopathies. However, further diagnostic tests such as an MRI or electromyography may be necessary for confirmation.
trial_0.multiturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Cervical Radiculopathy or Brachial Plexus Injury.
trial_0.singleturn_mcq:
Final Diagnosis: Brachial neuritis (Parsonage-Turner syndrome)
